guide.title: Gentoo Linux Documentation Developer Policy
guide.abstract: This guide is a HOWTO for the Gentoo Linux Documentation Team. This guide will cover all of the basics of writing documentation for the Gentoo Linux Project, and it will be a contact point for new developers.

body.p: If you are reading this guide, then you are either a new documentation developer, or someone that wishes to contribute to the project. First, I would like to thank you for contributing to the Gentoo Linux project. Part of our goal is to create documentation that is easily accesible to the public. Our format is easily learned, so you will not have a hard time with the XML language. For more information on our XML format, please go here.
This guide will cover these items:

Even if you are not a developer, these guidelines still apply to you. If you are a developer, these guidelines should be your Gentoo Bible. There was much consideration put into these policies, and you are urged to follow them, and, if necessary contest them.

The first thing that every developer should do is read the Official Gentoo Linux Policy. This document is the collaboration of all of the developers, and it contains some extremely important information.

As a documentation developer, you should subscribe to the gentoo-doc mailing list. There is a lot of information that is contained on this list, and it is a good idea to keep updated what is going on.

When you commit something to CVS, it is EXTREMELY important that what you commit is fully functional and correctly proofread. I cannot stress how important it is that your documents are correct in every way. If you fail to proofread your documents, and consistently commit broken XML, there will be repercussions, such as revocation of CVS access.

It is your duty as a developer to check and complete your bugs on the buglist. Everyone pulls their own weight on the Gentoo Project. If you have a question, ask another developer, more often then not, they will be more than happy to assist you. Not addressing your bugs is a serious offense, and can lead to revocation of developer status.
Most importantly, respect your other developer colleagues.

Just like any well written program, it is very important that some formatting conventions are followed while writing Gentoo Linux Documentation. Let's start at the beginning of the document. Every document that is written for the Gentoo Linux project must have these headers at the top.

The first line ensures that the interpreter knows what version of XML it has to translate and what character encoding scheme it has to use. I will discuss character encoding later in this guide, but as of November 2002, all Gentoo Linux documentation is to adopt the UTF-8 (Unicode) encoding scheme.

The second line specifies the path where the DTD conversion sheet is. An explanation of the definition of a DTD Guide is out of the scope of this document, but if you are inquiring, you can definately do some research and get back to the rest of us.
The next line is very important. This sets the location of the document, and it must be set.
body.note: This is the opening guide tag, check the XML guide for more information.
body.pre: Replace x with the name of your document. <guide link = "/doc/your_country_code/x.xml">
body.p: All "<pre>" tags are to have captions that adequately describe their contents.
body.pre: <pre caption = "This is what my pre contains">
body.p: Like any well-written programming code, it is expected of documentation developers to properly indent their XML code with tabs. This has not been done much in the past, but it needs to be done in the future. This increases readability, and it is Just Good Programming (tm) practice.
You are required to write your name into the doc if you have made many changes to it. The "<author>" tags are to be used as follows:
body.li: If you are the original author, your title is "Author".

If the original author is no longer present, and you have assumed his/her position, your title is "Contributor". If you get prior permission to assume author status, you may do so, keeping the original author listed as "Original Author".
If you have made substansive changes to the document, your title is "Editor".
If you have made grammatical changes to the document, your title is "Copyeditor".
body.p: Organize your document. Coordinate your main points and sub points. Documentation that comes from Gentoo is to be professionaly laid out. Not only does this look good, it helps overall readability. Make good use of Chapter/Section delineation, it makes navigation by the drop down box very easy.
Use proper capitalization to recognize significance. i.e. gentoo linux == Gentoo Linux, kde = KDE, gnome = GNOME, etc.
MOST IMPORTANTLY, read the Gentoo XML Guide. There is a lot of important information contained within, and it should be read by anybody writing Gentoo Linux Documentation.

As of mid-November 2002, all of the new Gentoo Linux documentation is to be encoded in UTF-8. I will not go into the wonderful world of character encoding, but UTF-8 is an international standard that is recognized by any good browser. We are working on upgrading the old docs to UTF-8, and hopefully, sometime next year (2003), all documentation will be UTF-8 compliant.

Before commiting anything dealing with documentation, your documents must be checked/verified with xmllint and xsltproc. xmllint is more or less a syntax checker, and xsltproc is a full fledged XML-->HTML conversion engine.
Using xmllint is simple:
body.pre: # xmllint doc.xml It may be nice to use the --format switch, as it makes the output nicer.
body.p: Basically, if there are errors in your doc, xmllint will catch them and report them to you.

Of course, there are more options that can be used with both of these tools, and I urge you to explore those. The instances that I gave are just the basic ones that will check your documents for you.

The Gentoo.org website is a constantly dynamic and evolving webpage. Our website is based on a XML/XSL conversion system. If you have not noticed (eek), our whole website is coded in XML. Our XML code is transformed on the fly by a nice server-side kit named Axkit. In other words, every time that a XML document is requested, it is transformed on the fly into HTML. Now you can see why document accuracy is so important. If there is an error in the page's XML, it will simply not display. Again, make absolutely sure that your XML is flawless.

The Gentoo.org website can be found in the gentoo-src tree, under the gentoo-xml branch. All commits to documents are made in gentoo-xml/doc/your_lang/. Follow the naming convention of the files that are in the directory. If you are commiting in a new language that we do not yet have, contact a Senior Developer, and they will assist you in setting it up.
If you do not have CVS access, you must commit your docs using Bugzilla. Create a bug, and assign it to docs-team@gentoo.org. Please attach your guide in XML format to the bug.

For our documentation commits, we use plain old cvs commit. It is required of you to make a relevant good commit comment. We do not keep changelogs of the documents (that may change in the future), so we rely on the CVS commit comments. Remember that you are liable for what you commit to CVS. In other words, don't commit broken XML! You will face the wrath of Seemant and myself (not to mention the rest of the doc team).
If you have any questions on CVS, please consult the CVS Tutorial.
If you have any questions, please consult the people below:

tr.ti: Documentation Coordinator, Bug squasher, most everything (tm)

body.p: If I have forgotten anyone, I am sincerely sorry! I have included all of the major developers at this time. Do not hesitate to contact us if you have any questions.
